questions.text: A 29 y/o woman visits the doctor with symptoms of itching, burning, and a thick white vaginal discharge. She has no significant past history and is not on any medications. Examination shows erythema and swelling of the vulva and vagina, along with a curd-like discharge. A wet mount of the discharge reveals budding yeast and pseudohyphae. What is the suggested initial treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Metronidazole 500 mg orally twice a day for 7 days
Fluconazole 150 mg orally as a single dose
Fluconazole 300 mg orally as two split doses 72 hrs apart

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fluconazole 150 mg orally as a single dose

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of uncomplicated vulvovaginal candidiasis.

Uncomplicated Vulvovaginal Candidiasis:

  • Topical Antifungals: Duration: 1–3 days.
  • Products: Antifungal creams/suppositories for vaginal infection, external creams for vulvar symptoms.
  • Oral Antifungals: Single dose of fluconazole or itraconazole.

 

Complicated Vulvovaginal Candidiasis:

  • Topical Azole Antifungals: Twice daily for 7–14 days.
  • Oral Antifungals: Fluconazole: Second dose (150 mg) 72 hours after the first dose.
  • Vaginal Boric Acid Capsules: 600 mg in a gelatin capsule for recurrent infections.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with secondary infertility and a history of chronic pelvic pain. She has no prior surgical history but reports recurrent pelvic infections and menorrhagia. HSG is performed to evaluate tubal patency. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed on HSG in this patient?

choices.text: Bilateral tubal occlusion with a "beaded" appearance
Normal tubal patency with free spillage of contrast
Irregular endometrial cavity with regular uterine cavity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bilateral tubal occlusion with a "beaded" appearance

 

Explanation:

 

HSG Findings of Tubercular PID:

 

  • Rigid (lead pipes) tubes with nodulations in some places.
  • Tobacco pouch appearance with blocked fimbrial end.
  • Beaded appearance of the tube with variable filling density.
  • Bilateral tubal occlusion.
  • Vascular or lymphatic extravasation of dye.
  • Distal tube obstruction.
  • Coiling of the tubes or calcified shadows.
  • Bilateral cornual block.
  • Tubal diverticula and fluffiness of tubal outline.
  • Uterine cavity- irregular outline, honeycomb appearance, uterine synechia.

questions.text: In the management of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which of the following statements are not true regarding surgical intervention ?

choices.text: Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess required surgical drainage.
Mild PID symptoms controlled by antibiotics typically do not require surgery.
Surgery is often needed in chronic PID cases with recurrent pelvic pain
PID diagnosed early generally does not require surgical intervention unless complications develop.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Surgery is often needed in chronic PID cases with recurrent pelvic pain

 

Explanation: Chronic PID with recurrent mild pelvic pain is usually managed with antibiotics or analgesics. Surgery is not typically required unless there are complications such as abscess formation or severe disease.

 

Indication of surgery for PID:

  • Generalized Peritonitis.
  • Pelvic abscess
  • Tubo-ovarian abscesses that do not respond to antimicrobial therapy or rupture.
  • Life-threatening infections.

 

Active surgery used in PID:

 

Surgical intervention is reserved for severe or life-threatening complications of PID. Early detection and antibiotic therapy often prevent the need for surgery.

Patient characteristics

Choice of surgery

Ruptured abscess

Emergency laparotomy or laparoscopic drainage

Young women

Salpingectomy or Salpingo-oophorectomy

When extensive damage precludes conservative management.

  

Abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral Salpingo-oophorectomy

When the patient is multiparous and older age group

Mild case of PID, adequately treated.

  

Tuboplasty

Minimal damage, but infection may lead to infertility

questions.text:
Select the complications of tubercular pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) from the options below.

1. Peritonitis

2. Infertility

3. Ovarian cancer

4. Hydrosalpinx

5. Ectopic pregnancy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

Explanation:

Complications of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease:

  • Peritonitis: In severe cases, the infection can spread to the peritoneum causing widespread inflammation and infection.
  • Infertility: Tubercular PID can cause scarring and blockage of the fallopian tubes, leading to infertility.
  • Hydrosalpinx: The fallopian tube is blocked with fluid due to scarring and inflammation.
  • Ectopic pregnancy: Tubercular PID increases the risk of ectopic pregnancy due to damage and blockage of the fallopian tubes.
  • Chronic pelvic pain
  • Abscess formation
  • Adhesions and scar tissue
  • Chronic infections
  • Systemic spread

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Boer-Meisel prognostic system?

choices.text: Extent & severity of acute pelvic infection.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Extent & severity of acute pelvic infection.

 

Explanation:

The Boer-Meisel prognostic system plays a crucial role in helping clinicians and patients make informed decisions regarding the management of tubal infertility. It was described by Boer-Meisel & coworkers to prognosticate the chances of successful intrauterine pregnancy in patients with hydrosalpinx, following tubal reconstructive surgery. It scores the extent & severity of tubal damage.

Components of the Boer-Meisel system:

  • Extent of adhesions. (Option A)
  • Nature of adhesions (filmy or dense).
  • Size of hydrosalpinx. (Option C)
  • Macroscopic condition of the endosalpinx.
  • Thickness of tubal wall. (Option B)

 

 

 

Gainesville’s staging for PID, classifies acute PID in four clinical stages, depending on the extent of involvement & clinical severity. 

 

Stage

Description

I

Acute endometritis/salpingitis without peritonitis and no adhesions

II

Acute salpingitis with peritonitis and purulent discharge from tubal ostia

III

Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex

IV

Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess

V

Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text: In which cases can Actinomyces-associated pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) be seen?

choices.text: Women who have had a hysterectomy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Women using intrauterine devices (IUDs)

Explanation:

Women using intrauterine devices (IUDs) more than non-copper devices are prone to getting actinomyces-associated PID due to the following reasons:

  • IUDs can act as foreign bodies within the uterus, creating an environment that may facilitate the growth of certain bacteria, including Actinomyces.
  • Actinomyces can form biofilms, protecting bacteria from immune responses and antibiotics.
  • The presence of an IUD can disrupt the normal vaginal flora, potentially allowing pathogenic bacteria like Actinomyces to thrive.

questions.text: A 30 y/o married woman presents with a 2-month history of pelvic pain and irregular menstrual periods. She also reports a low-grade fever, weight loss, and night sweats for the last 2 months. On examination, she has mild tenderness in the lower abdomen. A pelvic ultrasound reveals a complex adnexal mass with ascites. Laboratory tests show mild anemia with an elevated ESR. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tubercular Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

 

Explanation:

The patient's history of low-grade fever, weight loss, and night sweats, combined with chronic pelvic pain and irregular menstrual periods, is suggestive of a chronic infectious process, specifically tuberculosis.

 

The pelvic ultrasound findings of a complex adnexal mass with ascites, along with the laboratory results of mild anaemia and elevated ESR, support a diagnosis of tubercular PID.

 

Clinical features of tubercular pelvic inflammatory disease:

 

Category

Symptoms and regards

General Symptoms
  • Fatigue, mild fever, loss of appetite, anaemia, night sweats, anorexia

Infertility
  • Common, affecting 70–80% of women
  • Caused by tubal damage, endometrial destruction, ovarian dysfunction

Menstrual Abnormalities
  • 50% have normal menstruation
  • Others may experience menorrhagia or irregular bleeding/Amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea

Chronic Pelvic Pain
  • Occurs in 20–30% of cases
  • Often linked with tubo-ovarian mass
  • May worsen with tubal patency test or secondary infections

Vaginal Discharge
  • Common in cervical or vaginal TB cases
  • This may include postcoital bleeding

Physical Examination Findings
  • Often insignificant (50% show no pelvic pathology)
  • General health may appear normal, but signs of extragenital TB (lungs, lymph nodes) may be present
  • Abdominal examination: Normal or tender, irregular pelvic mass, abdominal distension, rare ascites
  • Vaginal examination: Ulcers on vulva/vagina, thickened fallopian tubes, Nodules through posterior fornix, Bilateral pelvic masses
  • Rectal examination: Confirms vaginal findings, assesses uterosacral ligament involvement

 

Endometriosis (Option C) can cause chronic pelvic pain and irregular menstrual periods, but it usually does not cause systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and night sweats. A complex adnexal mass with ascites and elevated ESR is not typical for endometriosis, suggesting that tubercular PID is more likely.

 

Chronic pelvic pain syndrome (Option D) is a diagnosis of exclusion and is characterized by chronic pelvic pain without an identifiable infectious or structural cause. The systemic symptoms of fever, weight loss, night sweats, ultrasound findings, and elevated ESR indicate an underlying infectious or inflammatory process, making tubercular PID the more likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Arrange the following in descending order based on the most common site for tubercular pelvic inflammatory disease.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fallopian tube, Endometrium, Ovaries, Cervix

 

Explanation: Female Genital Tuberculosis (FGTB):

  • Most Commonly Affected Site: Fallopian Tubes ( in 100% of cases)
  • Other Common Sites (in order of frequency):
    • Endometrium (50–60%).
    • Pelvic Peritoneum (40–50%).
    • Ovaries (30%).
    • Cervix (5–15%).
    • Vulva and Vagina (1%).
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Secondary Infection: FGTB is almost always secondary to a primary infection, most frequently in the lungs (50% of cases).
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis spreads from the primary site through the bloodstream.
    • Vulnerability of Fallopian Tubes: Increased susceptibility due to the growth spurt of pelvic blood vessels during puberty.

questions.text:
The male partner should be treated along with the female partner in which of the following conditions?

i) Candidiasis

ii) Bacterial vaginosis

iii) Trichomoniasis

iv) Gonorrhoea

v) Chlamydia

vi) Chancroid
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) All except (i) and (ii)

 

Explanation:

Condition

Male Partner Treatment

Candidiasis
  • Male partners need not be treated except when symptomatic.
  • Use nystatin ointment locally for a few days after each instance of coitus.
  • Condom use is preferred during treatment.

Trichomoniasis
  • Follow the same treatment as the female partner:
    • Metronidazole 500 mg BD for 1 week, or a single 2 g dose.
    • Tinidazole 2 g single dose is also effective.
  • Use a condom during coitus until the female partner is cured.

Gonorrhoea
  • Cover gonorrhea, syphilis, and chlamydia.
  • Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM + Azithromycin 1 g PO once, or Doxycycline 100 mg PO BID for 7 days.
  • Use a condom until both partners are disease-free.

Chlamydia
  • It should be treated with the same regimen as the female partner to reduce resistance or recurrence.
  • Azithromycin 1 g once, or Doxycycline 100 mg BID for 7 days.
  • Abstain from sex until both partners are treated and asymptomatic.

Chancroid
  • Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose, Azithromycin 1 g PO single dose, or Erythromycin 500 mg PO every 8 hours for 7 days.
  • Longer treatment for HIV-positive patients.

Bacterial Vaginosis
  • Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is caused by an imbalance in the vaginal flora, particularly a decrease in lactobacilli and overgrowth of anaerobes.
  • Although it is more common in sexually active women, it is not classified as a true sexually transmitted infection (STI).
  • Multiple studies have shown that treating male partners does not reduce recurrence in females, so routine partner treatment is not recommended.

questions.text: A 33 y/o female with well-controlled diabetes reports four episodes of vulvovaginal candidiasis in the past year, presenting with itching, burning, and thick white discharge. Examination shows vulvar and vaginal erythema and swelling with curd-like discharge. A wet mount confirms Candida albicans. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommended treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Fluconazole 150 mg orally every 3 days for three doses
Fluconazole 150 mg orally every 3 days for three doses, followed by once weekly for six months
Fluconazole 150 mg orally as a single dose
Vaginal boric acid capsules 600 mg daily for 14 days

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fluconazole 150 mg orally every 3 days for three doses, followed by once weekly for six months


 

Explanation: The clinical vignette suggests recurrent C. albicans candidiasis.

Recurrent Candida albicans Candidiasis:

  • Treatment: Oral fluconazole 100-mg, 150-mg, or 200-mg doses once every third day for three doses (days 1, 4, and 7) or local intravaginal therapy for 7 to 14 days.
  • Prevention: Oral fluconazole 100 to 200 mg weekly for 6 months.

 

Recurrent Non-albicans Candida Species:

  • Treatment: Boric acid 600 mg gelatin capsule intravaginally at bedtime for 2 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common organism associated with pelvic inflammatory disease?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B. Chlamydia trachomatis

Explanation:

Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common organism associated with pelvic inflammatory disease.

Pelvic inflammatory disease:

  • Pathogenesis:
    • The infection ascends from the cervix and endometrium to the fallopian tubes and ovaries, causing inflammation and scarring. This can result in infertility, ectopic pregnancy, and chronic pelvic pain.
  • Aetiology:

Acute

Chronic
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  • Chlamydia trachomatis
  • E.coli
  • Mycoplasma genitalium
  • Anaerobes: Including Bacteroides species (Mixed infections)
  • Gardnerella vaginalis
  • Trichomonas vaginalis
  • Streptococci: Including Group B Streptococcus
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Actinomyces israelii

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with an intense burning sensation and thick vaginal discharge. She reports no foul odour with erythema on pelvic examination. A wet mount preparation is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vaginal candidiasis

 

Explanation:

 

Vaginal candidiasis is characterised by thick white vaginal discharge with a burning sensation and wet mount findings revealing pseudohyphae.

 

Vaginal candidiasis:

 

Causative organism
  • Candida albicans (Dimorphic fungi)
    • Blastospores: Transmission and colonisation
    • Mycelia: Tissue invasion & adherence

Symptoms
  • Pruritus, burning, and splash dysuria
  • Erythema and oedema on pelvic examination

Diagnosis
  • Curdy white discharge resembles cottage cheese
  • Vaginal wall plaque: petechiae when removed
  • Microscopy on KOH preparation: budding yeast and pseudohyphae (image).
  • Culture: Bismuth Glycine Glucose Yeast agar (BiGGYagar) or Nickerson agar (selective for candidiasis).

Types
  1. Uncomplicated candidiasis:
    1. In immunocompetant women
    2. Good prognosis
    3. Causative organism: C. albicans
  2. Complicated candidiasis:
    1. In immunocompromised women: DM, TB, pregnancy and chemotherapy patients
    2. Recurrent and difficult-to-treat.
    3. Causative organism: Non albican species like C. tropicalis, glabrata

 

Trichomoniasis (Option A) usually presents with a frothy, yellow-green discharge and may show motile trichomonads on wet mount.

 

Chlamydia (Option C) infection often has minimal symptoms or may present with a mucopurulent discharge.

 

Gonorrhea (Option D) typically presents with a purulent discharge, not seen in candidiasis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents with a yellow vaginal discharge and itching. A pelvic examination revealed an erythematous cervix. A wet mount preparation is shown below. Which of the following statements is not true about this patient's condition?

choices.text: It is the most common cause of non-viral sexually transmitted diseases worldwide.
The preferred treatment is a single dose of metronidazole.
Repeat NAAT testing after 3 days is required to confirm eradication of the infection.
Sexual partners should be treated simultaneously to prevent reinfection.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Repeat NAAT testing after 3 days is required to confirm eradication of the infection.

 

Explanation:The clinical vignette of a female with yellow vaginal discharge, pruritus, erythematous cervix and wet mount preparation showing trichomonads suggests trichomoniasis caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.

Repeat NAAT testing after 3 weeks is required only for follow-up testing for cases where symptoms persist or reinfection is suspected.

 

Trichomoniasis:

Most common non-viral STD worldwide (Option A).

Causative organism
  • Trichomonas vaginalis (anaerobic flagellate protozoan).

Clinical findings
  • Severe irritation and pruritus.
  • Foul, thin, greenish-yellow, frothy discharge.
  • Dysuria, dyspareunia, vulvar pruritus, and lower abdominal pain.

Diagnosis
  • Vaginal pH >4.5
  • Microscopy: motile trichomonads.
  • Colpitis macularis (strawberry vagina): subepithelial haemorrhage on cervix/vagina.
  • Lab-based NAATs for trichomonal DNA: (Option C)
    • Repeat test if suspect persisted infection/ re-infection.
    • Not distinguishing live from dead (adequately treated) trichomonas; hence, repeat testing delayed for 3 weeks.

Risk factor
  • Increase incidence with age.

Treatment
  • DOC: Metronidazole 500 mg (400 mg) BD for 7 days or 2 g orally once (Option B).
  • If allergy: desensitisation.
  • Treat sex partners (Option D).
  • Abstain sex and condom use.

questions.text: A 31-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester presents with fishy-smelling vaginal discharge. A wet mount examination revealed clue cells and diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. What is the recommended treatment for managing this condition?

choices.text: Boric acid suppositories, intravaginally for 5 days
Metronidazole 500 mg orally twice daily for 7 days
Tinidazole 2 g orally once daily for 2 days

questions.solution:
Correct answer (Option C) Metronidazole 500 mg orally twice daily for 7 days

Explanation:

Recommended treatment guidelines for bacterial vaginosis:

  • Metronidazole 500 mg orally 2 times/day for 7 days OR
  • Metronidazole gel 0.75% one full applicator (5 g) intravaginally, once a day for 5 days OR
  • Clindamycin cream 2% one full applicator (5 g) intravaginally at bedtime for 7 days

Alternative Regimes:

  • Clindamycin 300 mg orally 2 times/day for 7 days OR
  • Clindamycin ovules 100 mg* intravaginally once at bedtime for 3 days OR
  • Secnidazole 2 g oral granules in a single dose† OR
  • Tinidazole 2 g orally once daily for 2 days OR
  • Tinidazole 1 g orally once daily for 5 days

Any of the regimens used in non-pregnant women can be used in pregnancy. In the 1st trimester we usually prefer vaginal route, beyond 1st trimester - both vaginal & oral can be used

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Amsel's criteria for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis?

choices.text: Presence of clue cells on microscopic examination
Positive amine odour when alkali is added
Thin homogenous white discharge that unevenly coats the vaginal walls

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vaginal pH less than 4.5

 

Explanation: Vaginal pH of more than 4.5 is a part of Amsel's criteria.

 

Diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis:

 

  • Amsel's criteria: ≥3 out of 5: Diagnostic of bacterial vaginosis.
    • Thin, homogenous (creamy) white discharge. (Option D ruled out)
    • Whiff test: Release of volatile amines with KOH.
      • Secretion + 10% KOH → Amines → fishy odour. (Option C ruled out)
    • Saline wet-mount microscopy: Presence of clue cells. (Option A ruled out)
      • Vaginal epithelium with embedded bacteria and absent leukocytes.
    • Alkaline pH > 4.5.
    • Malodorous fishy odour. 
  • PCR: detection of rRNA of Gardnerella vaginalis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with malodorous vaginal discharge for the past week. On examination, she reports a white discharge coating the vaginal walls with no itching. Based on the clinical and microscopic findings (below), what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C

Explanation:

Bacterial Vaginosis is characterised by a thin, greyish-white discharge with the presence of clue cells (vaginal epithelial cells coated with bacteria).

Bacterial Vaginosis:

The most common cause of vaginal discharge in reproductive-age women.

Causative organism
  • Hemophilus (Gardnerella) vaginalis
  • Less common: Prevotella, Mobiluncus, and Bacteroides

Risk factors
  • Increased risk: multiple or new sexual partners, female partners, oral sex, douching, smoking, IUD use, black race.
  • Decreased risk: condom use

Associated conditions
  • PID and relapse of PID
  • Chorioamnionitis (PID in pregnancy)
  • IU death
  • Abortion
  • Puerperal sepsis
  • Vault cellulitis (After hysterotomy)

The image below shows normal vaginal flora and clue cells in bacterial vaginosis.

Candidiasis(Option A) typically presents with thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge and itching.

Trichomoniasis(Option B) presents with frothy, greenish-yellow discharge and often causes itching.

Chlamydia(Option D) is often asymptomatic but can cause mucopurulent discharge and other symptoms.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with severe lower abdominal pain, fever, and purulent vaginal discharge. She has bilateral adnexal and cervical motion tenderness on examination. Investigations show elevated WBC, positive swabs for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis, and bilateral tubo-ovarian abscesses on ultrasound. She is admitted to the ward. What is the most appropriate inpatient treatment for severe PID?

choices.text: Oral Doxycycline 100 mg BD and Metronidazole 500 mg BD
I.M Ceftriaxone 250 mg OD and oral Azithromycin 1 g OD
I.V Cefoxitin 2 g every 6 hours and Doxycycline 100 mg BD
Oral Levofloxacin 500 mg OD and Metronidazole 500 mg BD

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) I.V  Cefoxitin 2g every 6 hours and Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD

Explanation: 

I.V Cefoxitin 2 g every 6 hours and Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD is the most appropriate regimen for inpatients with severe PID complicated by tubo-ovarian abscess. Intravenous cefoxitin provides broad-spectrum coverage against many pathogens, including anaerobes, while doxycycline covers Chlamydia trachomatis and other possible co-infections.

In-patient antibiotic therapy

Parenteral regimen A

Cefoxitin 2 g IV every 6 hours for 7 days + Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 14 days

Parenteral regimen B

Clindamycin 900 mg IV every 8 hours + Gentamicin 2 mg/kg IV (loading dose), followed by 1.5 mg/kg IV (maintenance dose) every 8 hours

• Aztreonam (2 g IV slowly) is similar to aminoglycoside and can be used. It has no renal toxicity, but is more expensive.

Alternative parenteral regimen

Ampicillin-sulbactam 3 g IV every 6 hours 3-5 days + Doxycycline 100 mg orally BID for 14 days

Oral Doxycycline 100 mg BD and Metronidazole 500 mg BD (Option A) is not appropriate for severe PID with complications such as tubo-ovarian abscess. Oral medications are typically reserved for less severe cases or for continuation therapy after an initial response to intravenous treatment. Severe cases and those with complications require more intensive therapy.

I.M Ceftriaxone 250 mg OD and oral Azithromycin 1 g OD (Option B) is used for the outpatient treatment of uncomplicated PID; it is not suitable for severe cases with complications such as tubo-ovarian abscess.

Oral Levofloxacin 500 mg OD and Metronidazole 500 mg BD (Option D) is not suitable for severe PID with complications.

questions.text: A 24-year-old sexually active woman presents to the clinic with lower abdominal pain, fever, and unusual vaginal discharge. She is diagnosed with pelvic inflammatory disease. What is the most appropriate initial treatment regimen for this patient?

choices.text: Azithromycin 1 g PO OD + Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD X 14 days
Cefixime 400 mg PO single dose + Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD X 14 days + Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD X 14 days
Levofloxacin 500 mg PO OD X 14 days, and Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD X 14 days
Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875 mg/125 mg PO BD X 14 days, and Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD X 14 days

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Cefixime 400 mg PO single dose + Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD X 14 days + Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD X 14 days

Explanation:

 

Ceftriaxone, Doxycycline, and Metronidazole cover the spectrum of organisms commonly involved in PID.

  • Cefixime covers Neisseria gonorrhoeae, an important pathogen associated with PID.
  • Doxycycline covers Chlamydia trachomatis and other intracellular organisms.
  • Metronidazole targets anaerobes, often found in the pelvis polymicrobial infections.

In India the above drugs come in a Yellow kit for syndromic case management of STD.

Due to its comprehensive coverage, this combination is considered first-line therapy for PID outpatient management.

 

Male sexual partners should also be treated to prevent reinfection.

In India, the Grey kit (Cefixime + Azithromycin) is used to treat partners for STIs.

 

Out-patient antibiotic therapy

Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose or

Cefoxitin, 2g IM single dose and probenecid, 1 g PO single dose or

Injection Cefotaxime IV

Add Doxycycline 100 mg PO, BD for 14 days with or without Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD for 14 days

 

Other options:

 

Option A
  • Azithromycin is effective against Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • Azithromycin does not cover other pathogens, such as Neisseria gonorrhoeae and anaerobes.
  • Metronidazole targets anaerobic organisms, but this combination lacks coverage for Neisseria gonorrhoeae, making it suboptimal.

Option C
  • Levofloxacin is effective against organisms causing PID, such as Neisseria gonorrhoeae and anaerobes.
  • However, it is generally reserved as an alternative therapy when other first-line antibiotics cannot be used.
  • While Levofloxacin could be used as a first-line therapy, it is not recommended due to antibiotic resistance as it is used as a second line treatment for tuberculosis

Option D
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanate is broad-spectrum and effective against many bacterial infections.
    • It does not adequately cover Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Doxycycline covers Chlamydia trachomatis but not the polymicrobial nature of PID.
  • Therefore, this combination is suboptimal for treating PID according to current guidelines.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain, fever, and purulent vaginal discharge.The uterus is normal in size and there is no adnexal mass. There is mucopurulent discharge coming from the os.What investigation do you do next to guide the treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Endocervical swab culture

Explanation: An endocervical swab is crucial for guiding treatment in patients with suspected pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). It is the most appropriate next step as it detects key sexually transmitted pathogens, such as Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which are common causes of PID. Identifying the causative organism allows for accurate diagnosis and facilitates targeted antibiotic therapy, improving patient outcomes and minimizing the risk of complications.

 

Laparoscopy (Option B) is the gold standard for diagnosing pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) but usually not performed to diagnose acute PID. It allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs and the extent of inflammation, adhesions, and abscesses. It is particularly useful in uncertain cases or in patients who do not respond to initial treatment.

 

Pelvic ultrasound (Option A) can help assess the pelvic organs and show PID complications, such as abscess formation. However, it is not considered the gold standard for diagnosing PID as it may not detect all cases and lacks specificity.

 

Transvaginal ultrasound (Option D) provides detailed images of the pelvic organs and helps evaluate complications like tubo-ovarian abscesses. However, like pelvic ultrasound, it is not the gold standard for PID diagnosis because it may miss early or subtle signs of the disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with severe lower abdominal pain, fever, and abnormal vaginal discharge. She also notes pain during urination.Her LMP was 3 weeks ago. On physical examination, there is marked tenderness in the lower abdomen, and cervical motion tenderness is elicited. Laboratory findings reveal an elevated white blood cell count, and USG shows thickened fluid-filled fallopian tubes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

 

Explanation: PID is the correct diagnosis, given the symptoms of severe lower abdominal pain, fever, abnormal vaginal discharge, and pain during urination (dysuria). The presence of cervical motion tenderness and ultrasound findings of thickened, fluid-filled fallopian tubes strongly support this diagnosis.

Clinical Features of PID:

Signs
  • Fever
  • Purulent Cervical Discharge
  • Triad of PID: Cervical motion tenderness + Adnexal tenderness + Abdominal tenderness

Symptoms
  • Lower Abdominal Pain
  • Abnormal Vaginal Discharge
  • Dyspareunia (Pain during intercourse)
  • Dysuria (Pain during urination)
  • Menstrual Irregularities
  • Nausea and Vomiting

Laboratory Findings
  • Elevated WBC
  • Elevated C-Reactive Protein (CRP)
  • Elevated ESR
  • Ultrasound Findings: Shows thickened, fluid-filled fallopian tubes and free pelvic fluid.


 

Cervicitis (Option A) can cause vaginal discharge and discomfort, but it usually lacks the systemic symptoms of fever and significant lower abdominal pain seen in this case. Cervicitis primarily involves localized inflammation of the cervix and does not affect the fallopian tube

 

Appendicitis (Option B) presents with lower abdominal pain, starting around the umbilical and later radiating to the right lower quadrant. Fever and elevated white blood cell count are common. However, it usually lacks vaginal discharge, cervical motion tenderness, and does not present with pain during intercourse or urination.

 

Ovarian torsion (Option D) typically presents with a sudden onset of severe unilateral lower abdominal pain, often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. An adnexal mass may be shown on the ultrasound. However, it is less likely to present with fever, elevated white blood cell count, or abnormal vaginal discharge.
